situated in the tOwnshis of Orwell, Warren & Windham, in the County of Bradford, Penn sylvania, about 145 miles west of Newburg, 28 west of Montrose the seat of Justice of Susquehanna county Pa.; IA from Towanda, the county site of Bradford county; and 16 south of Owego, in the state of New York, and 10 miles cast of the Susquehanna river. Said Lands to be surveyed into lots to suit purchasers at the expense of the owner; at the low rate of $1 ,5O per Acre, Cash or S2, 50 on credit of four years, The subscriber hay ing resided on this tract of land for some years, can recommend the quality of the soil to be equal if not superior to any tract of land in the country for Grain, Grass S<c. timbered as follows, Uiz.-Becch, Maple, HemIOck, White wood, Cherry, Chesnut, Oak, Pine, S1c. well watered with pure, living water, with roads leading through the tract in different direc- tions, with aourishing settlements in different places on the tract, with Grist Mills and Saw Mills on and adjacent thereto. An indisputa- ble title will be given. The Subscriber has the title papers from the State, which are sat- isfactory to all who have examined them.

 For further particulars please call on the subscriber in Orwell Township, who will take satisfaction in showing the land.

 B. CHUBBUCK.

 December, 1926. 8w28
I4,OOO Acres Of LGnd

ming music. and was peculiarly agreeable to the husband and relations of the performer.

 'Oh; as to pleasing ones husband or reIa- tions, that is all Dicky, in the Haun-tOn, you know; but am determined to have one at any rate. Was it easily learnt, and was it taught by French or Italian masters ?

 It was easily learnt, but Frenchmen and Italians scarcely dared to show their heads in our country in those times

 Can you not possibly recoIlect the name How shall we know what to enquire for ]!

 Yes, 1 do now remember the name, and we must enquire for a SPINNING WHEEL

Soon after the British government had ac- knowledged American Independence, small American vessel entered the Downs, with the flag of tue U. s. display'd; but her comman- der was forced by the commanding naval of ficer on that station to lower his flag. The in cident produced the following couplet,

 These are the. triumphs, George thy annals

 boast. cock-boat humbled and an empire lost

ClX months from the date hereof are all 0 lowed byathe Hon. Court of Probate for the District of Litchfeld to the Creditors of the Estate of

 Dea. SAMUEL NORTON, late of Goshen, within said district deceased to exhibit their claims to the subscribers. All claims not exhibited within said time will be barred recovery. .- MIRANDA NORTON, Erecutrir.

 WILLIAM STANLEY, }

 LEWIS M. NORTON, A@N''"'''S Goshen, Dec, 20, 1926. 28
NOTICE.

FOR THE COUNTY POST. An! who can tell What late befel His dOgship-lack-a-daisy Ne muses nine

 Grant me a line, Or shall sure be crazy.- With drinking high, One night when nigh Where Bacchus wav'd his banners, He with smack, "Swore white was black" And damn'd our country manners. He had head! Twas {" city bred" And eyes that naught could see too; But he can stare !- My heart-beware For Whither canst thou flee to? He rais'd his eye, .-.- His nose 6 sky high'' With spectacles was straddled; Ye mortal men What wonder then That my poor brain is added. But oh /! his bark !! When all was dark How royalty it sounded; His yeIping too The canine crew, They skulk'd away confounded. His brother came, Like him by name, And every like" by natur i; Like him his style Of dress, and smile; The charming little cratur! Ye canine race To him give place, And own there's not another, Of yelping crew Ye ever knew, Could beat him, and his brother. For me alas {" It came to pass'' That1 was half destracted, When both, I saw, Walk on to law, How wonderous wise they acted,

 J. H.
roR THE COUNTY PosT,

ITS hereby given that the Board of Relief for l the town of Litchfed, will meet at the County House on the first Monday of Janua- ry next at ten o'clock in the forenoon, to hear and determine all appeals to them made from the doings of the Assessors and to equaize & adjust the valuations and assessments of said Town.

 JOHN WEIGH, )po,ra oe

 DAVID MARSH, Dodiu ol

 JONATHAN BUEL, nenel Litchfeld, Dec. 19, 1926. 28
NOTICE

FVHE annual meeting of fDARIUSCHAP-

 A TER & St. PAUL'S LODGE for the choice of officers will be held at the Masonic Hall, on Thursday. the 2sth of Dec. Inst.- the Chapter at 10 o'clock, A. M. and the Lodge at 2 o'clock, P. M. Dec. 25, 1926.
MASONIC NOTICE.

Estate of Caleb Morgan, late cf Kent, deceased.

 The Administrator represents the Estate insolvent, and prays the appointment of Com mssioners thereon Ordered, That Com missioners to receive and examine the claims of the Creditors of said Estate be appointed at the Probate Office in New Milford on the 9th day of January 1927 at l2 o'clock at noon: of which all persons in interest will take no- tice and appear if they see cause and be heard thereon.

 true Copy of Record,
DISTRICT OF NEw-MILFORD, ss. Probate Court, Dec. 9th, 1926. {

A IMPEACHMENT FOR THE LADIES.

 Thy grandmother,' said my uncle Toby. addressing himself to young Arabella, just from London, and who was playing the bat tie of Marengo, on the piano. thy grand mother, child,' said he, used to play on a much better instrument than thine.'

 Indeed said Arabella, how could it have been better? you know 1t is the most fashion able instrument, and is used by every body that is any thing

 Your grandmother was something, though she never saw a piano forte.'

 But what was the name of the instrument had it strings, or was it played by keys ? \

 You must give me time to recolect the name; it was indeed stringed instrument, but was played by the hand.'

 By the hand alone ?-How vulgar; but protest should like to see one, and pappa shall buy me one when return to Lon don. Do you think that we can obtain one r

 No, you will not probably find one in Lon don. but doubtless they may be found in some ofthe country towns.'

 How many strings had it Must one play with both hands and could one play the double bass ? f''' @

 know not whether it would play double bass, as you call it, it was played with both hands and had two strings li E Two strings only surely you are testing !; how could good music be produced an such an instrument, when the piano has two or three hundred? ?

 On, the strings were very long. one about IA feet, and the other might he heightened at pleasure, even to 50 or mOre.'

 What prodicious deal of room it must take up, but no matter, I will have mine in the old hall, and pappa may have an addition built to it, for he says shall never want for any thing, and SO does mamma. Were the strings struck with little mallets like the piano, or were they snapped like harpsichord?' r

 Like neither of those instruments as re- collect, but it produced soft kind of hum
cock boat humbled and an empire lost
ATTACHMENT FOR THE LADIES.

FFHE Hon. Court of Probate for the dis A trict of WOodbury, having allowed six months from the goth day of Nov. 1926, to the Creditors of the estate of

 HANNAH GALPIN,,

 late of Washington, in said district, deceased, insolvent, to exhibit their claims, and appointed the subscribers Commissioners Ito receive and examine the same. We there fore give notice that we will attend to the bu- siness of our Appointment at the dwelling house of Daniel B. Brinsmade in said Wash lington;; on the ed Mondays of March and A. lprll 1897, atone O'Clock P. M. All persons who fail to present their claims by the time limited as aforesaid will be barred recovery. CONSTANTINE McMAHON, } c lHERMANNS MARSHALL, Ccm"''s- JOHN HUDSON, S'o"efs.

 Washington, Nov. 20, 1926. s7

 The Executors represent the Estate insol- vent, and pray the appointment of Commis- sioners Ordered, That Commis- sioners to receive and examine the claims of the Creditors of said Estate be appointed at the Probate Office in Woodbury, on the Sd Monday of January 1927 at 10 o'clock, fore noon: of which al! persons in interest will take notice and appear if they see cause and be heard thereon. 2s c. TO ACTUAL sETTLERs.

A letter from Capt. Clapperton, the traveller, in Africa, dated in February last states he has made important discoveries, having passed over rauge of hills that were before not known to exist, and trav- ersed one of the largest kingdoms of Af- rica, the name ofwhich had not yet reach edEurope. The River Niger was but two days journey from him, and its course to the sea through the Eight of Benius could no longer be doubtful. s.

From the Maidstone Gazette.

 PROFLIGATE PIG.

 On Tuesday, person living in Maid stone, left home with his famly,to pick hops. Being afraid that the pig, in the sty might be stolen, they transferred him to the cellar. After some time, piggy contrived to ascend into the kitchen, and inspect the cupboard in that he found about pounds of bacon, which he, in most cannibal-like manner, devoured. His repast soon sed sought for something to allay his thirst, and, in the course of his researches, he smelt savory in the upper regions. Accordingly he scrambled up stairs into a bedroom. There he found wherewith to wash down thf bacon, for on the floor he found sever- al bottles of elderberry wine. ''Drawing of corks" he did not understand but in 'cracking a bottle, /" he proved himself to be as dexterous as any bon OiUent in the parish. Bul his freaks nov drew to a close; poor piggy got as ''drunk as Dayid's sow;" he capered about, threw down the chairs, upset certain utensil, broke the wash-hand basin, and swallowed the soap. The last performance proved the cause of great a. arm to the neighborhood for in the gaity of his heart, he got up on his hind legs, aud, with his snout all over soap suds, and his masters night-cap on his head, looked out of the window, for the benifit of the air.-Being observed, gteat outcry was raised and it was quickly rumored that there was a mad pig, foamimg ot the mouth, looking out of a chamber window in Carey street: and the tipsy poker,by all accounts, certainly had very queer look. It was proposed to shoot him to prevent further mischief; but after much pro and con, a resolute man went up, and by a little skill ful manGuvering, poped poor piggy into a poke, brought him safely down, and he was deposited in his sly, without other damage to himself than being a little the scorse for Nquos. s

 Wonderful.-There was exhibit ed, few weeks ago, in boat at the market sreet landing place, ,Steubeny.lle, ilae bones of a non-descript animal, one of which is 20 feet in length, 8 in width, and weighs upwards Of twelve hundred pounds. The back bone is l6 inches in diameter, and lated from the size of the bones that the animal, when living, must have been about fifty feet in length, 20 to 26 feet in width, and about 20 in heighth and that it must have weighed at least 20 tons. These bones were found near the Mississippi river, ill i've believe) Louisiana and form tlIe greatest natural curiosity that we ever be- held. This animal must have as far trans cended lhe mammoth i'll size, as the nanl- moth common bulldog.-EEerald.

 Mir. Carter, in a recent letter to his partner of the N. Y. Statesman, says that, |''oweing.to the religious zeak of the Ouch ess D'Angouleme, and disposition of the government to increase the influence of the Church with hope of rendering it subservient to State purposes, France is at present almost as pries-ridden as it was before the Revolution. Monas;ic in- stitutions are encouraged. Ecclesiastical fraternities are multiplied, and the ear is stunned with the ringing of bells during all hours of the day and night. Swarms of ignorant, lazy, and frequently vicious priests are quartered upon the people; the yeriest drones of society, serving no other purpose than paid the cause of legit;ma- cy. The number both of soldiers and ecclesiastics Is much greater in the south of Paris, since the sentiments and afec- tions ofits inhabitants are supposed to be less loyal and not so fully under tho eye of the government ...,

 A letter from Capt. Clapperton, the traveller, in Africa, dated in February last states he has made important discoveries, having passed over a rauge of hills that were before not known to exist, and trav- ersed one of the largest kingdoms of Af- rica, the name of which had not yet reach edEurope. The River Niger was but two days journey from him, and its course to the sea through the Eight of Beniusi could no longer be doubtful.

 The London Sunday Times, of the 22d ut. contains the following rather startling ans nouncement to the admirers of honest JoLn Bunyan, and many of his sfriends will regret to find that with regard to his being the author of fPilgrim's Progress, ' beholdit is a dream The narapranh is eas follows. HrThe friends

 ANDREW BROWN,

 ELIRUR WILSON. Cornwall, Dec, 1e, 1896. s7

"ILL be sold at Public Auction on the w 2d day of January 1927, at o'clock A. M. atthe house of the late Samuel Gum, deceased, all the persona! property of the de- ceased consisting of household furniture, far ming utensils, stock, Sc. Conditions made known at time of sale.

AUCTION SALE.

AME into the enclosure of the subscri- W bsr about the l0th inst. small black yearling, BULL, no Artificial mark. The owner is requested to prove property, pay charges, and take him away.

 JAMES WAUGH. Litchfeld s. Farms, Dec. sS, 1926. 27
ESTRAY.

On tue disintermeat of tue remains of Com. O.

 H. Perry, by an officer Q the Lexington. From his lonely grave by the sea washed sand To the cline of lis fame we bore him, For he could not rest in foreign land With the red cross waving OCT him So we covered his breast with the stars of light In the flag that he loved SO dearly, When he met the proud foe in his might, And the battle followed cheerly. % With mourning flag haIf-mast displayed, We reused our drums to meet him, ! And fore and aft we stood arrayed, With minute guns to greet him: . White<memory showed him ever nigh As he looked when fame had crowned him, With victory becoming from his eye, And freedom cheering round him. Like some bright fewer that meets its doom, Where the scorching winds have hasted; Like some young pine whose mountain bloom, The bolts of Heaven have wasted a- So fell the beautiful and brave,

 In the zenith of his, glory, With nations tears to wet his grave, And embalm his name in story.

 Then strew his bier with early flowers, And wave the laurel OCT him,

 Who made the sea's proud Mistres "ours," What none had done before him.

 Let ocean hear and roll along, Till winds and floods are weary;

 While music wakes the chords of song, For the Hero of Lake Erie.

 Soon after the British government had ac-
ELEGY,

AME into the enclosure of the subscri- W bsr about the l0th inst. small black yearling, BULL, no Artificial mark. The owner is requested to prove property, pay charges, and take him away.

 JAMES WAUGH. Litchfeld s. Farms, Dec. sS, 1926. 27

full articles.headline: ELEGY,
full articles.article:
On tue disintermeat of tue remains of Com. O.

 H. Perry, by an officer Q the Lexington. From his lonely grave by the sea washed sand To the cline of lis fame we bore him, For he could not rest in foreign land With the red cross waving OCT him So we covered his breast with the stars of light In the flag that he loved SO dearly, When he met the proud foe in his might, And the battle followed cheerly. % With mourning flag haIf-mast displayed, We reused our drums to meet him, ! And fore and aft we stood arrayed, With minute guns to greet him: . White<memory showed him ever nigh As he looked when fame had crowned him, With victory becoming from his eye, And freedom cheering round him. Like some bright fewer that meets its doom, Where the scorching winds have hasted; Like some young pine whose mountain bloom, The bolts of Heaven have wasted a- So fell the beautiful and brave,

 In the zenith of his, glory, With nations tears to wet his grave, And embalm his name in story.

 Then strew his bier with early flowers, And wave the laurel OCT him,

 Who made the sea's proud Mistres "ours," What none had done before him.

 Let ocean hear and roll along, Till winds and floods are weary;

 While music wakes the chords of song, For the Hero of Lake Erie.

 Soon after the British government had ac-
